title: Is the NFL a passing league or a rushing league?
text:
When you think of the modern NFL, what players do you think of? Most of the time, people think of elite quarterbacks or wide receivers or running backs. The names range from Patrick Mahomes to Justin Jefferson to Derrick Henry.
However, there was an issue brewing recently that sparked controversy in the NFL: Running backs weren’t being paid as well as they should. Running backs like Johnathan Taylor and Josh Jacobs were having contract issues throughout 2023. There were even kickers that were out earning running backs.
This begs some questions: Is the position of running back dying in the NFL? Is the NFL focusing on the passing game? Let’s look at the last two decades, 2001-2010 and 2011-2020. With the exception of the 2001 season, each season had 32 teams playing. This was also before the NFL officially moved to a 17-game regular season.
The Pro Football Reference shows the NFL’s history of offense, both on the ground and in the air.
First, we will ask the question: Is the passing game giving the run game a chance to flourish in the NFL?
We will divide each year’s receiving yards by rushing yards to create a factor called “Net Yards.” This indicates that for every one rushing yard, there is a number of receiving yards to that one rushing yard. The bigger the “Net Yards,” the bigger the difference between receiving and rushing yards.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(ggrepel)
library(readr)

passing_rushing_totals_sports_reference <- read_csv("passing_rushing_totals_sports_reference.csv")


Rows: 93 Columns: 15
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (15): Rank, Year, Tms, RushingAttempts, RushingYards, RushingTD, Rushing...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
nfl <- passing_rushing_totals_sports_reference |> 
  filter(Year >= 2001 & Year <=2020) |>
  mutate(
    NetYards = ReceivingYards/RushingYards
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=nfl, 
    aes(x=RushingYards, y=ReceivingYards, size=NetYards),
    alpha = 0.3) +
  scale_size(range = c(2,8), name = "NetYards") +
geom_point(
    data = nfl, 
    aes(
      x = RushingYards, 
      y = ReceivingYards, 
      size = NetYards),
    alpha = .3,
    color = "black") +
geom_text_repel(
    data=nfl, 
    aes(x=RushingYards, y=ReceivingYards, label=Year)) +
geom_vline(xintercept = 58189.71) +
geom_hline(yintercept = 121042.3) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x = "Rushing Yards", y = "Receiving Yards",
    title = "The NFL lacks consistency on the run game",
    subtitle = "The 2010s emphasized offense in the air more than the 2000s, especially in the mid-2010s.",
    caption = "By: Josiah Dames | Source: [Pro Football Reference] (https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/NFL/rushing.html)"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 60250, y = 122000),
    label = "A Season's Rushing Yards",
    size = 3,
    color = "dark grey"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 58195, y = 140000),
    label = "A Season's Passing Yards",
    size = 3,
    color = "dark grey"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 57000, y = 135000),
    label = "Huge emphasis on passing offense",
    size = 3
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 60000, y = 100000),
    label = "Huge emphasis on offense on the ground",
    size = 3
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









Code
nfl |>
  summarise(
    RushMean = mean(RushingYards),
    ReceiveingMean = mean(ReceivingYards)
  )


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  RushMean ReceiveingMean
     <dbl>          <dbl>
1   58308.        121588.


As we look at the two decades of football, the 2000s show that they emphasize the run game a lot more and there isn’t much difference between the yards in the air or on the ground. The 2010s, however, were all over the place.
(WHAT WAS GOING ON IN THE NFL AT THAT TIME???)


Code
decadeone <- nfl |>
  filter(Year >= 2001 & Year <= 2010)

decadetwo <- nfl |>
  filter(Year >= 2011 & Year <= 2020)

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=nfl, aes(x=Year, y=RushingYards), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=decadeone, aes(x=Year, y=RushingYards), color="red") +
  geom_line(data=decadetwo, aes(x=Year, y=RushingYards), color="blue") +
  labs(
    y = "Yards Per Attempt",
    x = "Year",
    fill = "Yards Per Attempt",
    title = "The run game failed in the 2010s",
    subtitle = "2004 had gained more yards while 2020 struggled to move the ball per attempt.",
    caption = "By: Josiah Dames | Source: Pro Football Reference"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )











Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=nfl, aes(x=Year, y=ReceivingYards), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=decadeone, aes(x=Year, y=ReceivingYards), color="red") +
  geom_line(data=decadetwo, aes(x=Year, y=ReceivingYards), color="blue") +
  labs(
    y = "Yards Per Attempt",
    x = "Year",
    fill = "Yards Per Attempt",
    title = "Offense in the air consistently grows each year",
    subtitle = "2017 dropped the passing game's effectiveness but picked back up.",
    caption = "By: Josiah Dames | Source: Pro Football Reference"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









However, when we look at both decades, there are some years that did better than others.
Then this begs the question: where does each team rank individually with their rushing and receiving yards?


Code
big <- passing_rushing_totals_sports_reference |> 
  group_by(Year) |> 
  summarise(
    SeasonRushingYards = sum(RushingYards),
    SeasonReceivingYards = sum(ReceivingYards),
    TotalOffensiveYards = SeasonRushingYards + SeasonReceivingYards,
    .groups = 'drop'
  ) |> 
  filter(Year >= 2001 & Year <=2020)

biglong <- big |> 
  select(-TotalOffensiveYards) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = ends_with("Yards"),
    names_to = "metric"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=biglong, aes(x=reorder(Year, value), weight=value, fill=metric)) + 
  coord_flip() +
labs(
    y = "Season Yards",
    x = "Year",
    fill = "Season Yards",
    title = "2020 balanced rushing and receiving yards",
    subtitle = "The 2010s dominate receiving yards compared to the 2000s.",
    caption = "By: Josiah Dames | Source: Pro Football Reference"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









But what about each years’ efficiency on both rushing and receiving yards? Surely the better year would have more yards per attempt on both sides of offense.


Code
big <- passing_rushing_totals_sports_reference |> 
  group_by(Year) |> 
  summarise(
    SeasonRushingYardsPerAttempt = RushingYards/RushingAttempts,
    SeasonReceivingYardsPerAttempt = ReceivingYards/ReceivingReceptions,
    TotalOffensiveYards = SeasonRushingYardsPerAttempt + SeasonReceivingYardsPerAttempt,
    .groups = 'drop'
  ) |> 
  filter(Year >= 2001 & Year <=2020)

biglong <- big |> 
  select(-TotalOffensiveYards) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = ends_with("Attempt"),
    names_to = "metric"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=biglong, aes(x=reorder(Year, value), weight=value, fill=metric)) + 
  coord_flip()  +
labs(
    y = "Yards Per Attempt",
    x = "Year",
    fill = "Yards Per Attempt",
    title = "2011 achieved more yards per attempt on both sides",
    subtitle = "2004 gained more yards on average compared to 2020 per attempt.",
    caption = "By: Josiah Dames | Source: Pro Football Reference"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









It’s safe to say that 2004, while not having as many rushing yards compared to the 2010s, was a very effective year.

title: About
text: My name is Josiah Dames and I am a Sports Media major at the University of Lincoln-Nebraska. I am a sports reporter for The Daily Nebraskan and Unlimited Sports and I am a part of a NFL podcast on YouTube. I am a huge fan of both college and pro football. My dream job would be to work with a professional football team and edit, record, and write about the team.
